docs.lead_paragraph: There are inklings around the city of a movement toward a learning philosophy that promotes creative play; in Brooklyn, one program takes toddlers into Prospect Park and teaches them to dig in the mud.
docs.abstract: Ginia Bellafante Big City column observes that some New York City parents are trending away from achievement-based child-rearing and toward slow parenting, promoting simple experience and learning by creative play and imitation in child's early years.

docs.lead_paragraph: When Michelle R. Titus won a special election for a seat in the Assembly in April, she predicted that despite the decisiveness of her victory, she would face tough competition later in the year in the Democratic primary. Her prediction has come true, and then some. Ms. Titus is immersed in a race for the Democratic primary in the 31st Assembly District in Queens with five other candidates, some of whom have run for office before and others who are well known to voters. The district includes several neighborhoods in the southeastern part of the borough.
docs.abstract: Six candidates seek Democratic nomination in 31st Assembly District in Queens, including Michelle R Titus, who won special election for seat in April; photos; photos; map (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: HOW a working-class Irish girl from South Boston became a chef with a national reputation for making pasta is one of those virtually unanswerable nature-vs.-nurture questions. But to watch Barbara Lynch as she mixes dough with her hands and feeds it into an old pasta machine that's no bigger than a home model is to see a young woman with the soul of an Italian grandmother. Wouldn't she save time by using a food processor?
docs.abstract: Barbara Lynch, chef and owner of No. 9 Park in Boston, prepares tagliatelle with Tuscan meat sauce in The Chef series; recipe; photo (M)

legacy.MultimediaSummary1: What makes a computer an effective teaching tool? A teacher with an idea.

multimedia.credit: What makes a computer an effective teaching tool? A teacher with an idea.
multimedia.caption: Teachers at Work

docs.lead_paragraph: EIGHTY-ONE percent of students from grade school through high school use computers in their classrooms, according to a Census Bureau report, while there are now 4.4 computers for each public-school child in the United States, a 2003 report by the National Center for Education Statistics said. So it seems natural to assume that teachers use computers to enhance learning, but when it comes to computers, all assumptions are off. ''Even today, the majority of teachers are reluctant to use technology,'' said Robert McLaughlin, executive director of the National Institute for Community Innovations in Montpelier, Vt., who is trying to get cheaper access to the Internet for institutions as well as free technology tools for schools. ''They don't regard it as something that will help them be more effective with their students.''
docs.snippet: It seems natural to assume that teachers use computers to enhance learning, but when it comes to computers, all assumptions are off. What makes a computer an effective teaching tool? A teacher with an idea....

headline.main: These Teachers Teach Tech to Teachers

docs.abstract: IDC predicts that the market for Big Data technology and services will reach $16.9 billion by 2015, growing at 40 percent a year. The research firm's report makes the case that Big Data is moving well beyond the "science project" phase into the commercial mainstream.
